abstract.p: Ireland's gross domestic product in first quarter of year increased 11.7 percent compared with first quarter of 1999; gross national product increased 8.8 percent versus same period; consumer spending increased 9.6 percent, and investments in new buildings and capital equipment rose 16.6 percent; results coincide with warning from Harvard economics professor Michael Porter that Irish economy faces stagnation because of lack of innovation in indigenous industry (S)

block.p: Ireland's gross domestic product in the first quarter of the year increased 11.7 percent compared with the first quarter of 1999, according to a government report. Gross national product, which includes the many multinational investments in Ireland, increased 8.8 percent versus the same period. Consumer spending increased 9.6 percent, and investments in new buildings and capital equipment rose 16.6 percent. The results coincided with a warning from a Harvard economics professor Michael Porter, who was speaking in Cork, that the Irish economy faced stagnation because of a lack of innovation in indigenous industry.

Ireland's gross domestic product in the first quarter of the year increased 11.7 percent compared with the first quarter of 1999, according to a government report. Gross national product, which includes the many multinational investments in Ireland, increased 8.8 percent versus the same period. Consumer spending increased 9.6 percent, and investments in new buildings and capital equipment rose 16.6 percent. The results coincided with a warning from a Harvard economics professor Michael Porter, who was speaking in Cork, that the Irish economy faced stagnation because of a lack of innovation in indigenous industry.
